div1.p: ROLL OF HONOR.

The Secretary of War, Hon. Elihu Root, in his annual report 1903
said with reference to the conquest of yellow fever in Cuba in 1900-1901:

“The brilliant character of this scientific achievement, its
inestimable value to mankind, the saving of thousands of lives, and
the deliverance of the Atlantic seacoast from constant apprehension,
demand special recognition from the Government of the United States.”

The Congress has, in concurrence with this opinion, by an Act
approved February 28th, 1929 authorized and directed the Secretary
of War to publish annually in the Army Register a Roll of Honor on
which shall be carried the following names, and to define in appropriate
language the part which each of these persons played in the experiments
during the yellow fever investigations in Cuba.
MAJOR WALTER REED, Surgeon U.S. Army.

Born 13 September, 1851 in Gloucester Co., Virginia. He graduated in
medicine at the University of Va., and entered the Army 1875. When sent to
Cuba in June 1900 at the head of the Yellow Fever Board of medical officers,
Reed was already a distinguished man. In the Spanish War he had been at the
head of another famous Medical Board which studied the camp epidemics of
Typhoid Fever in the Army during that war, and made a great advance in our
knowledge of the spread of that formidable disease in Armies. He was professor
of pathology and bacteriology at the Army Medical School, and also at the
Columbian University in Washington, and stood high in his profession. In the
work of the Yellow Fever Board he shared their labors and dangers, but his was
always the originating, directing, and controlling mind.1 He died in Washington
D.C., 23 November, 1902, following an operation for appendicitis.
(I). Address of Gen. Leonard Wood, p.48- Yellow Fever A Compilation, S. No. 822

DR. JAMES CARROLL, Acting Assistant Surgeon, U.S. Army, later Major Medical Depart-
ment.

Born in England 10 March, 1854. He enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1874, and
served until 1898 in each of the non-commissioned grades from corporal to first
sergeant and then as hospital steward. He took advantage of his opportunities
to study medicine, and when on duty in Washington under Reed to graduate as a
Doctor of Medicine. In 1898 he was appointed an Acting Assistant Surgeon, and
assigned to duty as Reed's assistant. Early in the study of the agency of the
mosquito as the transmitter of yellow fever, he volunteered to be bitten by an
infected mosquito. On 31 August, 1900 he became ill and suffered a very severe
attack of that disease. His was the first experimental case. He returned to
Cuba a year later to make special studies of the blood of yellow fever patients.
He died in Washington, D.C., 16 September, 1907, having been promoted to the
grade of Major, Medical Department by special authority of Congress in recogni-
tion of his services as a member of the Yellow Fever Board.
DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE, Acting Assistant Surgeon, U.S. Army.

Born in Cuba in 1869, the son of a Cuban Officer who fell in battle against
the Spaniards. He grew up and was educated in New York where his mother had
taken refuge, and graduated in medicine at Columbia University where he was the
classmate of Lazear. He entered the Army in 1898 and when appointed a member of
the Yellow Fever Board was with the Army in Havana in charge of the Army Medical
Laboratory. His special qualifications as a pathologist, and his energy and
ability contributed greatly to the success of the Board. Of especial value were
his contributions to the demonstration by the Board disproving the then generally
accepted theory that the bacillus icteroides was the causative agent of yellow
fever. He is now Professor of Pathology at the Medical School of the University
-3-
of Havana, and is the only member of the Board now living.
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR, Acting Assistant Surgeon, U.S. Army.

Born in Maryland 2 May, 1866. He graduated in Medicine at Columbia
University, N.Y., and did postgraduate work at the Pasteur Institute in Paris,
and at Johns Hopkins University, specializing in mosquitoes and their relation
to malarial infections. When the Yellow Fever Board was organized he was already
in Cuba on duty with troops, and was studying yellow fever. He had charge of
the mosquitow work of the Board when he contracted yellow fever while visiting
yellow fever patients in order to infect mosquitoes for experimental purposes.
He died 25 September, 1900 of this disease, a martyr to science. By his special
knowledge and brilliant scientific attainments, as well as by the invaluable
notes of his observations made in the last weeks of his life which he left,
he contributed in the highest degree to the successful outcome of the investigation.
? JAMES A. ANDRUS2, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born in Fassett, Pennsylvania in 1879, volunteered for experiment and was
infected with yellow fever by an injection of blood from an experimental case.
He became ill 28 January, 1901, being the 12th case in the series of cases at
Camp Lazear. He left the Army in 1902 with character excellent.
JOHN R. BULLARD,

Born in Massachusetts, and a graduate of Harvard University where he was a
distinguished athlete. Came to Cuba and was treated by Dr. James Carroll at
Columbia Barracks for malarial fever. Becoming interested in the yellow fever
work, he volunteered and received on 15 October, 1901 an injection of the filtered

-4-
blood of a Spaniard, an experimental case. Slight fever and discomfort were
caused, but no illness. N week later he received a blood injection from the
veins of an American soldier who had been infected by an injection of filtered
blood, and became ill with yellow fever 23 October, 1901. Having thus become
immune, he continued to reside in Cuba after his recovery.
A.W. COVINGTON, Private 23rd Battery, C.A.C.

Born 1877 in Laurinburg, North Carolina. Volunteered for experiment in the
third series of cases when it was well understood that yellow fever would be
the result. He was given at 11.05 A.M., 15 October, 1901 a subcutaneous injection
of 3 c.c. of the diluted and filtered blood serum from an experimental case of
yellow fever. He became ill 19 October with a typical attack of yellow fever,
from which he made a good recovery, and was returned to duty with his battery.
He remained in service twenty five years thereafter, being retired 9 August, 1926.
WILLIAM H. DEAN, Troop B. 7th Cavalry.

Born 1877 in Holland, Ohio. He was the second case of experimental yellow
fever, being that which convinced the Board that the theory of its conveyance
by mosquitoes was well grounded, and being mentioned in their preliminary report
as the Case X.Y. He volunteered and was bitten 31 August, 1900 by the same mos-
quito which had infected Dr. Carroll four days before. He was also bitten by two
other mosquitoes which had bitten a fatal case of yellow fever 12 days before,
and a fourth mosquito which had been fed on three severe cases of yellow fever.
He became ill 7 September, 1900 and suffered a well marked case ofnyellow fever.
He left the service 17 August, 1902, with an excellent character, and died 3 May,
1928.
WALLACE W. FORBES, Private, Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born 1878 in Galesburg, Illinois. He volunteered for experiment and received
22 January, 1901 an injection of half a cubic centimeter of blood from a case of
experimental yellow fever. Two days later he became ill and suffered a severe
attack of yellow fever. Private Forbes was discharged from the Army four years
later with character excellent.
LEVI E. FOLK, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born 1870 in Kadish, South Carolina. He volunteered for experiment, and
was one of the group who underwent the trying ordeal of sleeping twenty one con-
secutive nights in the soiled bedding used by yellow fever patients. This experi-
ment was of vast importance commercially as well as scientifically, as it upset the
accepted belief as to how the disease was transmitted, and resulted in the aboli-
tion of expensive disinfections. He later was bitten by infected mosquitoes, and
on 23 January suffered an attack of yellow fever of moderate severity, this showing
that he was susceptible to the disease when he slept in the infected bedding. He
was retired in 1923 after twenty five years of honorable service.
PAUL HAMANN, Private 23rd Battery, C.A.C.

Born 1876 in Germany and enlisted at Springfield, Illinois. He volunteered
for experiment, being one of the third group of volunteers, and was infected by
Dr. Carroll with filtered blood serum at the same time with Private Covington. He
became sick on 19 October, 1901 and suffered a moderately severe attack of yellow
fever. After fifteen years service he was discharged 12 August, 1913 with
character excellent.
JAMES E. HANBERRY, Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born 1875 in Denmark, South Carolina. He volunteered for experiment, and
was one of the group ofxxxx who slept twenty one consecutive nights on bedding
-6-
which had been used by yellow fever patients, and was soiled with their bloody
discharges. He also wore at night the soiled garments of the sick. Some weeks
after this disagreeable, and as it was then thought dangerous, experience, he
was bitten by the same two mosquitoes which had a few days before infected a
companion, and on 9 February, 1901, came down with a severe attack of this painful
disease. He left the service in 1902.
WARREN G. JERNEGAN, Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born 1872 in Cone, Florida. He volunteered for experiment and was one of
the group of seven who underwent the long and trying ordeal of sleeping in the
soiled and infected bedding and clothing of yellow fever patients. He then, on
28 and 29 December, 1900, submitted to the bites of infected mosquitoes, but
escaped infection. On 4 January, 1901 he received an injection of blood from a
case of experimental yellow fever (Martinez) and suffered a sharp attack of that
disease. He left the military service at the expiration of his enlistment with
character excellent, and went to Panama where he was employed in the Canal service
for a number of years. He died 5 February, 1919, in Charleston, South Carolina.
JOHN R. KISSINGER, Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born 1877 in McClure, Ohio, and enlisted for the Spanish War at Indianapolis,
Ind. He and Moran were the first to volunteer of those who underwent the conclu-
sive experiments experiments at Camp Lazear where they occupied the same tent.
On 20 Nov., 1900 he was bitten by three infected mosquitoes. On 23 November he
was bitten by one of the same three and on 5 December he was again bitten by
five mosquitoes, two of which had been infected by fatal cases. On 9 December
he became ill and suffered a typical attack of yellow fever. His was the first
case of experimental yellow fever in the series at Camp Lazear. Of him Major
-7-
Walter Reed said: “In my opinion this exhibition of moral courage has never
been surpassed in the annals of the Army of the United States”. He was
discharged from the service 14 November, 1901, with character excellent.
JOHN J. MORAN,

Born in Ohio and served as a Volunteer in the 2nd Division VII Army Corps.
After his discharge with character excellent he was employed as a clerk at the
Department Headquarters at Marianao. He there did clerical work for Major Reed
and became interested in the work of the Yellow Fever Board. He and Kissinger
were the first to volunteer for the conclusive series of experiments at Camp Lazear.
He was bitten on 26 and 29 November by infected mosquitoes, but without result.
On 21 December, 1900 he twice visited the infected mosquito room, and again next
day, and was repeatedly bitten. On Christmas Day he became ill, and suffered
a well marked and severe attack of yellow fever. Moran refused to accept the
bonus which was given by the Governor of Cuba to each volunteer, stating that he
was glad to be able to do this service to humanity. He afterwards served for some
years at Panama during the construction of the Canal, and is now a resident of
Havana.
WILLIAM OLSEN, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born 1874 in Pierce Co., Wisconsin. He enlisted for the Spanish War and came
to Cuba where he volunteered for the experimental work of the Yellow Fever Board
at Camp Lazear. He was one of a group of four who were given injections of blood
from a case of experimental yellow fever at the Camp, the Spaniard Martines, in
order to decide certain questions of scientific importance. He was taken ill
with yellow fever 11 January 1901. Private Olsen was discharged on expiration
of his enlistment 15 November, 1901 with character excellent.
CHARLES C. SONNTAG, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born 1872 at Charleston, South Carolina. He volunteered for the experiments
at Camp Lazear, and was bitten by two infected mosquitoes and came down with
yellow fever 10 February, 1901, being the last case in the series at Camp Lazear.
He took his discharge 12 December, 1901, with character very good.
CLYDE L. WEST, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army,

Born 1877 in Mier, Indiana. He enlisted at Toledo, Ohio for the Spanish
War, and came to Cuba where, while serving at Columbia Barracks, he volunteered
for the experiments at Camp Lazear. He was infected in the mosquito room by the
bites of two mosquitoes which had bitten a case of yellow fever 51 days before.
These caused a mild attack of yellow fever three days later on 9 February, 1901.
Six days later these same mosquitoes caused the very severe case of Hanberry in
which his life for several days hung in the balance. Private West was discharged
10 July, 1902, with character very good.
ROBERT P. COOKE, Acting Assistant Surgeon, U.S. Army.

Born 1874 in Virginia. He entered the Medical service of the Army 9 June,
1900, and was on duty at Pinar del Rio during the yellow fever epidemic in the
garrison there. He volunteered for the experiments at Camp Lazear and with two
privates, Folk and Jernegan, were the first to undergo the trying ordeal of
sleeping 21 successive nights in the soiled bedding used by yellow fever patients.
This was to determine whether the disease could be transmitted by infected bedding,
clothing, and other objects. This experiment was of vast importance not only in
making clear the method of transmission of the disease, but to the commerce of the
world. Dr. Cooke resigned from the Army 2 December, 1904.

THOMAS M. ENGLAND, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army, now Captain Medical Administra-
tive Corps.

Born 1876 in Ohio. He enlisted for the Spanish War and came to Cuba with
the VII Army Corps. He volunteered for the experiments at Camp Lazear, and under-
went the trying ordeal of sleeping 20 nights in the beds formerly occupied by a
yellow fever patient, and in the garment worn by him. His head lay on a towel
stained with the blood of a case of yellow fever. He remained in the Army, serving in
all the non-commissioned grades of the Medical Department, and won his commission
in that Department during the World War.
JAMES HILDEBRAND, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born 1862 in Georgia. Served in the Spanish War and came to Cuba with the
VII Army Corps. He volunteered for the experiments at Camp Lazear, and with England
underwent the trying ordeal of sleeping 20 nights, 11 Jan. to 31 Jan., 1901, in the
bed and the garment used by a yellow fever patient, and with his pillow covered by
a towel stained with yellow fever blood. Hildebrand then offered to be bitten by
infected mosquitoes, but Major Reed refused to permit this as he was much older than
the other volunteers, and the mortality in yellow fever is much increased with age.
He was discharged 17 August, 1914 with character excellent.
EDWARD WEATHERWALKS, Private Hospital Corps, U.S. Army.

Born 1874 in New Jersey. He enlisted for the Spanish War and came to Cuba with
the VII Army Corps. He volunteered for the experiments at Camp Lazear and underwent
the trying ordeal of sleeping 21 nights, 21 December, 1900 to 10 January, 1901
inclusive, on bedding which had been used by yellow fever patients and was soiled with
their bloody discharges. He wore at night the soiled garments of the sick. As
this experiment, like the other exposures to infected clothing had no result, Weather-
walks was bitten on 25 January, 1901, by twelve infected mosquitoes, but for some
reason not known escaped infection. He was discharged 21 December, 1901, with
character good, and died 21 October, 1916.
MEMORANDUM FOR THE ADJUTANT GENERAL.

With reference to the military records of the enlisted men and
Mr. John J. Moran, who was a discharged soldier, the records of the
Surgeon General's Office, and data received by that office from the
Adjutant General do not show the records in the Spanish War of these
men. It is recommended that this be looked up, and that it be stated
with regard to each one the fact that he served during the Spanish War,
if such was a fact, and the volunteer regiment or organization of the
Regular Army in which they enlisted, with the date. The members of the
Hospital Corps taking part in these experiments were nearly all men who
had served in volunteer regiments, and had enlisted in the Hospital
Corps when their organizations were mustered out of the service.
